summary: This document is a chain of emails between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel discussing the handling of Touhy requests (requests for government information) from victims of Jeffrey Epstein involved in civil litigation. The emails focus on procedural decisions, potential Giglio disclosure obligations, and coordination regarding the release of documents from the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: John McEnany
persons.context: A prosecutor in the SDNY involved in making determinations on Touhy requests related to the Epstein case, expressing concerns about Giglio disclosures and procedural matters.

persons.name: Steven Kochevar
persons.context: The point person for handling Touhy requests from Epstein victims, drafting response letters and coordinating with the criminal team and other offices.

persons.name: Alex
persons.context: A prosecutor involved in discussions about the legal theory behind Touhy requests and Giglio, and coordinating with victim's counsel.

persons.name: David Jones
persons.context: Copied on email discussions regarding the handling of Touhy requests and procedural approaches.

persons.name: Maria Lacerda
persons.context: Identified in an email as a Jane Doe victim who is a plaintiff in a civil suit and has made a Touhy request for documents.

persons.name: Robbie Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney (Roberta Kaplan) at Kaplan Hecker representing an Epstein victim in civil litigation, who is the recipient of initial Touhy procedure letters.

persons.name: Jeffrey O
persons.context: Mentioned briefly as someone John McEnany spoke to about designating Steven Kochevar as the point of contact for Touhy requests.

persons.name: Sarah
persons.context: Referred to as a 'wiser Touhy head' in the Civil Division to be consulted on complex procedural questions.

persons.name: Geoff
persons.context: Mentioned hypothetically as the 'responsible' U.S. Attorney who might receive a referred Touhy subpoena from another district.

persons.name: Rossmiller
persons.context: Mentioned in draft language as the initial recipient of a request for information, to be handled by another AUSA.

connections.description: Prosecutors within the SDNY U.S. Attorney's Office collaborating on the legal and procedural handling of Epstein-related Touhy requests.
Work together on responding to victim requests, with Alex providing legal perspective and Steven handling communications.
Engage in legal debate over whether complying with a Touhy request constitutes a benefit that must be disclosed under Giglio.
Kaplan is identified as the attorney representing victim Maria Lacerda in civil litigation against Epstein's estate.
Kochevar, as the government's point person, corresponds with Kaplan regarding the procedures for her client's Touhy request.
McEnany consulted with Jeffrey O about designating Steven Kochevar as the point of contact for Touhy requests.

events.title: Designation of Touhy Point of Contact
events.description: John McEnany emails Alex and Steven Kochevar to confirm that Steven will be the point of contact for Touhy requests related to Jeffrey Epstein from civil litigants.

events.title: Response to Victim's Touhy Request
events.description: Steven Kochevar circulates a draft letter and documents for production in response to a Touhy request from an Epstein victim (Maria Lacerda).

events.title: Follow-up on Victim's Touhy Request
events.description: Steven Kochevar updates the team that requesters have follow-up questions and that the office intends to tell them no further documents will be produced, and to direct requests for S.D. Fla. materials to N.D. Ga.

events.title: Maxwell Team Approval of Touhy Response
events.description: Steven Kochevar sends an updated response letter to a Touhy request, noting that 'The Maxwell team is okay with this version of the letter.'

events.title: Giglio Disclosure Debate
events.description: John McEnany and Alex debate whether communications with a victim (VB) regarding Touhy requests are disclosable as Giglio information (impeachment material) that could benefit her civil case.

keyFacts: The SDNY U.S. Attorney's Office was actively processing Touhy requests (for government documents) from victims of Jeffrey Epstein involved in civil litigation against his estate.

Prosecutors debated whether complying with such requests and the associated communications could constitute a 'benefit' to a victim/witness that must be disclosed to the defense under Giglio obligations.
The office had a specific policy to avoid obtaining files from the U.S. Attorney's Office in S.D. Fla. due to conflict issues, discovery issues, and the prior non-prosecution agreement.
The 'Maxwell team' (presumably Ghislaine Maxwell's defense) was consulted and signed off on at least one version of a letter responding to a victim's Touhy request.

The emails reveal coordination challenges between different U.S. Attorney's Offices (SDNY, S.D. Fla., N.D. Ga.) regarding which office was responsible for responding to requests for investigative materials from the Florida Epstein investigation.
